column6: From respondents experience, looks like the "programmer shortage" is more of a matching problem. Has worked in QA for 20 years and more than 10 years in testing automation. Still gets queries in Linkedin for development positions even though does not consider oneself as a programmer. Though work still requires one to know python, c#, labview etc. Either head hunters are incompetent or a tactic of mass-spamming everyone with certain keywords in their profiles and hoping some of them would take the bait. Another problem is that companies seek senior level developers with more than 3 years of experience on specific technologies. But almost everyone in the field with even some experience in programming are employed in some fashion. Schools create new professionals to the market, but they might not have enough opportunities to show their skills and thus enter full-time work. The freshly graduates and beginners need contacts in companies that could help with landing jobs. Companies and schools should work together to create touch points to working life and possibly land internships in thse companies. The respondent would want to see this more in the university universe so this programmer shortage would be mitigated.

column1: Kyllä. Pula sopivista osaajista pitää paikkansa.
Kyllä. Pula sopivista osaajista pitää paikkansa.
column6: It's unclear where exactly the shortage is. Management often still does not undestand what digitalization, AI, ML, IoT and the evolution of work practices actually means. If there would be understanding, there would be creators for good projects and we could pinpoint the shortage better. Another issue is with recognizing people's strenghts. This is partly the fault of consultants and their use. Often other professionals than programmers should be there to solve problems with programmers to identify the real problem which is to be solved with software. The consultant -problem is that client is prepared to pay for programmers, but not for problem solvers. This leads to hiring only programmers or to make programmers do the work of consultants. When you add the agile disruption which needs people as well. This would require increased undestanding with clients (especially with healtchare-sector). We see that understanding and competence is lacking. There is a shortage in talent, but what exactly is needed and how to identify the gaps is the real question.

column1: Kyllä. Pula sopivista osaajista pitää paikkansa.
column6: The shortage depends a lot on the specific domain and niche. E.g. web development vs. low level embedded dev. The company where the person works has grown steadily along the years. Hard to guess how the market is going to develop.

column6: Does not believe in programmer shortage as there's professionals available if really needed. At least if basics are in order: salaries and working conditions. Wonders why there's narrative of 10000 programmer shortage. It's dangerous as there's definitely no need for that many programmers. Many times requirements are set to far too high. You should be at the same time a full stack programmer in 10 languages, designer, cloud expert, sales negotiator and everything else.

column6: Real shortage seems to be in senior-level employees. As a junior, the respondent gets good offers, but even the current company one works for gets lots of applicants and a lot of them will get a negative reply. In that sense, plenty of supply available. Experience is another thing. Suspects a "winner-takes-it-all" situation where the most renowned companies get to pick the best of the crop and others have to work with less experienced or skilled programmers

column6: Not much of shortage. The difficulty is more in finding the real rough diamonds from a pile of varied quality applicants. From 100 recruitments, maybe 10 have been good. From these half were juniors with less than 5 years of experience but with open minds and common sense. The most common toxic patterns with bad programmers: Wants to reinvent the wheel as it's fun. Does not care about budgets. Is used to using certain patterns and won't be willing to move out from comfort zone. Can't handle imperfections. Lack's motivation aside from monetary compensation and requires close supervision.

I think employers should rather seek for people with right attitude and motivation. This type of person surely learns the niche technology if does not know it already. Employers are arrogant (though becoming less so) and the recruitment processeses and interviews might be belittling towards the candidate.

column6: Finnish programming industry is mostly around consulting, where companies sell CV's, which means that there's shortage of seniors or at least ones, who work for junior salaries. Head hunter can fill a position if one compensates clearly more than from your existing job. I know a lot of cases where work is hard to find as your CV might not look "sellable." The problem is that you need work experience first in order to land a job. I claim that Finland lacks companies that build their own products that would be comfortable on paying juniors who are learning to become seniors. Consultancies could make investments to develop juniors into becoming top players, but that would cut from company profits as juniors expect salaries as well and thus making this approach unpopular.

column6: Companies want to pay very little and then wonder when there's no takers. Has encountered clients trying to buy work for half the price requested. Offers two solutions for recruitment problems: Better wages on par with neighboring countries and improvements in recruiting services with sufficient skills on evaluating experience

column6: Programmer shortage is from experienced and multi-disciplined professionals, not on beginners or for people with less than 5 years of experience. And not just for programmers. Shortage also in other adjacent professions. Data communications, enterprise system management, firewall configuration, authentication, load balancing, storage, virtualization, cloud management etc. Really hard to find skilled people for these niches in Finland and almost impossible outside the capital region. Often the only option is to buy services from international consultants. Waiting for service might take years.

column6: "Programmer shortage" might be a misleading wording, but it feels like ICT-business has a chronic problem with technical professionals. Partly it could be due to wide spectrum for job descriptions we consider as "programmers", which can lead to bad (or completely nonexistent) onboarding practices. And when you add the high labor mobility of ICT-companies, it might be a situation where there actually is enough professionals, but making them productive is such a complex and hard to solve problem that it looks like a chronic shortage of builders.

column6: Some fields have too much labor, others have too much jobs. At least in ICT, the issue isn't like in many other fields where companies seek for free trainees and complain how hard it is to employ people.

Kyllä. Pula sopivista osaajista pitää paikkansa.
column6: Companies should invest themselves in training new professionals if they have trouble finding candidates with advertisements.

column1: Kyllä. Pula sopivista osaajista pitää paikkansa.
column6: The education does not prepare for the niche (IoT, embedded) they seek. Credible candidates all come from the hobbyist scene.

column1: Ei. En usko pulatilaa olevan.
column6: If there would be a shortage, then candidates would not be treated badly. Interviews are too exhausting. Homework assignments are unclear, recruiters are incompetent, communication is inhumane and the processes take months.

column1: Kyllä. Pula sopivista osaajista pitää paikkansa.
column6: Does not believe short intensive courses for people changing professions is a sustainable way to increase amount of programmers Says that inexperienced developers will create more need for experienced ones.

column1: Kyllä. Pula sopivista osaajista pitää paikkansa.
Kyllä. Pula sopivista osaajista pitää paikkansa.
column6: The shortage is real in sense that out-of-the-box professionals that companies seek do not exist. Companies have very tight criteria for what employees should know and can't see the path where juniors develop into seniors or a skilled senior can learn a new language or stack when needed. Especially consultancies have need for makers who can generate billable hours. But it's not sustainable either that the same people are moving around from company to another after the best benefit packages. Companies that develop their own products could more easily hire juniors and help them develop in their duties.

column1: Ei. En usko pulatilaa olevan.
Kyllä. Pula sopivista osaajista pitää paikkansa.
